body_html: This is because numpy doesn't properly handle RNG states when fork subprocesses. It's numpy's issue with multiprocessing tracked at numpy/numpy#9248). But we do provide some workarounds, e.g. the worker_init_fn in DataLoader (see http://pytorch.org/docs/master/data.html#torch.utils.data.DataLoader). Or you can use other start methods like spawn.
body_text: This is because numpy doesn't properly handle RNG states when fork subprocesses. It's numpy's issue with multiprocessing tracked at numpy/numpy#9248). But we do provide some workarounds, e.g. the worker_init_fn in DataLoader (see http://pytorch.org/docs/master/data.html#torch.utils.data.DataLoader). Or you can use other start methods like spawn.
body: This is because numpy doesn't properly handle RNG states when `fork` subprocesses. It's numpy's issue with multiprocessing tracked at https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/9248). But we do provide some workarounds, e.g. the `worker_init_fn` in DataLoader (see http://pytorch.org/docs/master/data.html#torch.utils.data.DataLoader). Or you can use other start methods like spawn.
